p: Q-methodology was implemented for the empirical investigation of the study. William Stephenson ( 1953) developed Q-methodology to enable the investigation of subjectivity in an objective manner (Ramlo & Newman 2011). It is a research method that amalgamates qualitative and quantitative techniques as it ‘encompasses a distinctive set of psychometric and operational principles … conjoined with statistical applications of correlational and factor analytic techniques, (thus providing) researchers with a systematic and rigorously quantitative procedure for examining the subjective components of human behaviour’ (McKeown & Thomas 2013:ix). Ultimately, the research method has a quantitative procedure to extract qualitative subjectivity and opinions as communicated through self-reference by the research respondents (Cross 2004; McKeown & Thomas 2013). Here subjectivity refers to behavioural patterns that form an individual’s perceptions, beliefs, attitude, opinions or point of view in a current situation, for example, perceptions of risk (Stephenson 1953).
